Ottawa, December 13, 1946.

Dr. Michel Tetreault, Indian Agent,
Pierreville, P.Q.

Attendance of White Children at Odanak Indian Day School.

We have for answer your letter of December 7 concerning the above problem. The point you raise in paragraph 3 of this letter is one which will have to be further investigated.

The Department would like to ascertain the following facts:

1. How many whites are living on the Reserve with permission?

2. How many children are there of school age in this category who would wish to attend the Odanak School if permission were given?

3. Is there sufficient room in the school to accommodate these children?

4. How many whites are living on the Reserve without permission?

5. How many children of school age in this category would wish to attend the Odanak School if permission were given?

If such authority is given, the Department will assess a small tuition fee for each child in order to assist in the maintenance and repair of the school and its equipment.

........ Your comments
Your comments in paragraph 3 are appreciated and you will realize the necessity for caution on the part of the Department in investigating the situation thoroughly before granting this permission.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

In response to your letter of December 13th concerning the white families living on the Indian Reserve of Odanak, to my knowledge none of these whites has permission to live there.

Eighteen children of school age (6 to 16) are on the Reserve. I have called the principal of the school to know if there was room in the school for such an additional number of pupils. The answer is no. Last fall we have installed a domestic science class in one of the class-rooms; this leaves only two rooms for the pupils. This is sufficient for the actual number of children. In the present circumstances the principal and I do not believe we could accommodate more than seven or eight more children.

It would be perfectly just and fair to assess a tuition fee for each child if permission is granted. This would certainly be accepted, for every one who came here seeking favour to send their children to the Indian school, were willing to pay.

Attached is a list of the whites living on the Reserve with their ages, names and children's ages.

Yours truly,

Dr. Michel Tetreault
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, January 10, 1947.

Ottawa, January 17, 1947.

Reverend Sister:

On the 29th October, 1945, we forwarded to Reverend Sister St. Rene, Grey Nuns of the Cross, Ottawa, cheque No.33235, for $139.75, drawn in favour of Sister St. Cleophyre, formerly teacher at St. Francis Indian Day School, being refund of Retirement Fund account. The Department of Finance have advised this office that due to a clerical error, Sister St. Cleophyre was overpaid the amount of $10.00. Would you kindly obtain a refund of this amount from Sister St. Cleophyre in order to adjust the overpayment. On the 8th May, 1946, we wrote to Sister Claire-Madeleine, Principal, The Grey Nuns of the Cross, Odanak, Que., requesting her to obtain a refund of this overpayment but to date we have not had a reply from her. However, Mr. P. N. L. Phelan of the Training Division has informed us that you are now the principal of the school and we trust that you will give this matter your prompt attention.

Yours truly,

N. E. Beach
Chief Treasury Officer.

Sister St. John of the Cross,
Principal,
The Grey Nuns of the Cross,
Odanak, Que.

Memorandum: ACTING DEPUTY MINISTER

We have Mr. Pratt's memorandum of Jan. 18th regarding the letter from Mr. Lucien Dubois, M.P. under date of Nov. 25th, 1946.

Following receipt of that letter, we have been in communication with the Indian Agent and from the information that we have received from him, it was considered advisable to have one of the Departmental officials visit Pierreville.

It has been arranged to have Mr. Doucet go to the reserve next week and as soon as he returns, a complete report will be supplied.

Director.

Reverend and dear Sister:

I understand that you have been appointed Principal of the St. Francis Indian Day School for the academic year 1947-48. I enclose one of our regular application forms which you should complete and return. I also enclose forms for Sister Ste. Jean Berchmans and Sister Ste. Basilisse. Memorandum:

CHIEF TREASURY OFFICER

Re: Francis R.C. Indian Day School, No. 326.

The staff at the above school, effective September 1, 1947, is as follows:

1. Sister Rose de Ste. Marie, Principal, Grade I - $1,680.00
2. " St. Jean Berchmans, Teacher, Grade II - $1,560.00
3. " Ste. Basilisse, " Grade II - $1,560.00

All the above salaries are for the academic year of 10 teaching months, in accordance with the regulations of the Indian school teachers' salary schedule as approved by Treasury Board.

Attached is staff questionnaire for Rose de Ste. Marie, who is a new teacher. The other two Sisters have been in our employ and new documents are not required for them.

All the above are members of a religious order and are not liable for income tax.

Au Docteur Maurault, Agent.

Monsieur l'Agent,

À mon arrivée à Ottawa, je fus grandement surprise, d'y trouver une lettre du Département m'annonçant qu'une retenue de 10% serait faite sur notre salaire, à partir du 1er avril, pour l'année courante. Je regrette beaucoup de n'avoir pas eu cette lettre plus tôt ; car j'aurais traité de l'affaire, de vive voix, avec M. Ferrier, par qui la lettre est signée. Je vous prie de vouloir bien faire remarquer au Département que nous avons accepté gratis les élèves protestants, ce qui lui donne une économie, étant obligé de soutenir une école dont les dépenses se chiffraient près de $1000.
Il serait raisonnable, par les circonstances,
de maintenir notre salaire tel qu'il est ;
ou si la chose n'est pas possible, du moins,
ne faut considérer les salaires des trois
maîtresses comme un tout, mais bien
séparés et ne dépassant pas $700.

Je vous prie aussi de bien vouloir
demander l'autorisation pour l'achat
des prix, n'oubliant pas les petites pro-
testantes qui ont droit, eux aussi, à
leur part.

Veuillez M. l'Agent vouloir bien
transmettre ma supplique au Département
des affaires Indiennes. En faisant,
vous obligez beaucoup,

Votre très humble,
Sr Marie Josephine, s.g.c.
Pierrefitte, May 13.

Refusant à la votre numéro 152857, je dois vous dire que la maison d'école catholique des Algonquins est de la dimension suivante : de longueur en longueur, soixante-dix-sept pieds de largeur et cent pieds de hauteur d'un plancher à l'autre, ce qui donne quatre mille quatre-vingt sept pieds et deux cubes. Le haut de la maison qui est divisé en deux parties, une partie, mesure seize pieds et trois quarts de large sur vingt-cinq pieds de long et sept de hauteur, ce qui donne une superficie de six mille neuf cent trente et un pieds et un quart cubes.

Le nombre des élèves de cette école étant de quarante, cela donne à chaque élève au moins de cent pieds cubes d'air dans le bas seulement, et le haut quoique n'étant pas utilisé pour les classes, avant ou après le moment des institutions, est la classe dans le bas, de sorte que les deux ensemble, bas et haut de l'école donnent à chaque élève au total de 170 pieds cubes d'air.

La dite maison d'école est en très bonne condition, ayant été parfaitement restaurée il y a peu d'années.

Secretary,

Sir,

Observing for some years a rapid increase in
the number of pupils who attend very regularly our Roman
Catholic school, whose number has reached sixty-seven this
year according to the present list of the school mistress,
Rev. Sister Marie Josephine, we consider it our duty to re-
present to you respectfully the great needs resulting there-
from if we desire to adapt matters to the requirements of
the Abenakis youth, who take great interest in education.

In fact for some years some of the parents
although poor have undertaken the burden of sending their
children -- some of their sons to the Nicolet College,
others their daughters to convents of St. François du Lac
and to Pierreville-- this is a good proof that this asser-
tion is worthy of consideration and if the school here were
equal to all the requirements of an increased attendance it
can quite be believed that still more pupils would be sent
and also to higher institutions such as those already men-
tioned.

In order better to prove the increase in the
number of pupils that have been attending the Roman
Catholic school of this tribe for some years, on referring
to the reports of the Department starting with the year
1891 at page 230 of the report, we find the total number of
pupils to be twenty-eight.

In 1896 under the same teacher, the Rev. Sister St. Lawrence, at page 405 of the report the number was forty-seven.

In 1899 the number of pupils was fifty, page 435 of the report.

This year having seen ourselves an increase of pupils more and more manifest, we have inquired as to the fact, and according to the report of the present teacher, the Rev. Sister Marie Josephine, the number of pupils has reached sixty-seven.

But while this increase is of a nature to encourage all those who take an interest in the education of youth, there are, however, many parents who complain and rightly so of the two things (1) a single teacher for sixty-seven pupils (2) a small school-house for such a large number of pupils.

In view of these facts, too many pupils for a single teacher and a school-room too small for the number and for the requirements of health, we consider it our duty to report these facts to the Department through our Agent, who is aware of these facts, in order that the Government may see to them as soon as possible and that on the opening of school next fall we may have a second teacher from the Grey Nuns of Ottawa, and also see the erection of a new school-house large enough for the present number of pupils and even for eighty who would attend school if they were not all crowded together as they are today.

And as the present school-house is three feet from the main road and there is no land for a playground for the pupils, it will be necessary also to change the site of the school-house by selling the present one to help in the building of a new one with as little delay as possible; otherwise some of the parents threaten to take
their children away on account of these two facts above mentioned, which naturally interfere with the march of progress and are a danger to the health of the children.

Awaiting a prompt consideration of these affairs by the Department, we have the honour to be, sir,

Your obedient servants,
Jos. Laurent, Chief.
Jos. deGonzague, Priest,
Missionary.
A.O. Comire,
Agent.

Sir,

I have already on several occasions remarked to the Department in my reports on the schools of the Abenakis village, that the Roman Catholic school is too small for the number of children that attend and also that there are no grounds for the children to play in, and before school and after school they play on the public roads, exposed to all kinds of dangers.

The school site has only a width of 38 feet by 50 feet in depth, and on this piece of land there is the school building and a wood-shed. You can imagine for yourself what remains.

I have already tried to hold negotiations with the owner of the neighbouring land in order to find out whether it would not be possible to make an arrangement to obtain a piece of land for the school children, but I have not succeeded. Sometimes my neighbour tells me that he does not want to sell; at other times he asks an exorbitant price. The present time is an occasion which it would be wise, I think, not to allow escape.

The Rev. Joseph Degonzaque, Roman Catholic Missionary, makes a generous offer of a piece of land about 75 x 200 feet on the south of the Roman Catholic church property.
please consult on this subject the special plan of the reserve and the book of reference in connection therewith made by Mr. C.C. Duberger in 1897.

No. 4 of the said plan shows the actual site of the school, No.5 indicates the Roman Catholic church property, and No.7 is the missionary's land. The church is built on No.5 and the presbytery under construction is on No.7. The missionary is also in possession of a piece of land of considerable size as far as the village goes, and this enables him to make the offer that I mentioned above. On this land it would be possible to build a school (including outbuildings) sufficient for present and future needs, and there would still remain sufficient land for a play-ground, where the children would be out of danger.

It is a magnificent site, far from the public road, and very suitable for a school.

I think that it would not be difficult to sell at a reasonable price the present school building, and its site, as a deduction on the price of a new school-house, and if we deduct from it the probable price that will have to be paid to purchase a piece of land to make a play-ground for the present school, it will reduce the cost of a new school-house to a relatively moderate price.

Therefore I think it would be wise, as I said before, not to let slip the present occasion of obtaining for nothing a suitable property for a moderate price, a school-house able to hold the ever-increasing number of children that attend.

Please take the matter into consideration and give me the views of the Department in this matter as soon as possible in order that a new building may be ready for the opening of school in the month of September next.

Sir,-

I have the honour to reply to your letter No. 152859/5, of the 27th June last as follows.

I think there will be about seventy children that will attend the Roman Catholic school next year; the number increases a little every year. Therefore, I think that a house 30 x 40 feet will not be too large if it is desired to conform to the laws of the Board of Health in regard to schools.

It might be built of two stories; this would not make a great difference in the cost of the building for the present, because only one story need be finished and the second one not until later when the necessity for it shall be felt.

I have consulted some builders here and I am told that the cost of a building of the dimensions described above with one story finished and the roof in galvanized iron would be about $1000.00 in wood-work not including painting; it would cost about $200.00 if built of brick.

I think that the old school-building might be sold for about $300.00, and if it is necessary to buy a piece of land to make a play-ground beside the old building, it would cost from $100.00 to $150.00 without considering the fact that the building would always be too small.
The cost quoted is only approximate, but in any case if the Department should decide to accept the offer of the Rev Mr de Gonzague, with the sum of $1,000 it is almost certain that a building could be erected which, without being finished, would completely meet the present requirements; it could be finished later or gradually as the need made itself felt.

Will you please take the matter into serious consideration and obtain a decision at once as possible in order that the building may be ready for the children by the opening of school, if the Department decides to erect one.

May it please Your Excellency:

Last spring we wrote to the Department of Indian Affairs to inform it of the great need that already existed of building as soon as possible another Roman Catholic school-house, much larger than the one we have at present, on account of the rapid increase in the number of pupils that attend the same, especially since 1885 when there were only 18 pupils.

The present school-house was built in 1886 at a cost of $400.00, $300.00 of which was paid out of the funds of the band, and $100.00 by a parliamentary grant as appears on page 203, part 2, of the report of the Department of Indian Affairs for 1889.

In 1889 the number of pupils was already 30 and in 1890 it was 50. This year, 1902, it is already 68, and in the fall it will certainly be 75, as the absentees are continually coming back.

For such a number we require also two teachers in place of one; otherwise some of the pupils must be neglected, and it will end by the parents becoming discouraged about sending their children where they will sometimes be without teaching owing to the number of pupils, and there will be danger for health on account of the schoolhouse being too small, having a dimension of only 24 X 30 feet.

The school-house ought to be 30 X 40 feet, two stories, with grounds 75 X 100 feet for a play-ground for the children, of which they are at the present time deprived, the land around the school being only 38 X 50 feet.
which is reduced by the 24 X 30 feet, the size of the school house erected thereon. The land can be bought—75 X 100 feet—for about $60.00.

The present small school-house, which already requires repairs, might be sold for about $200.00 or $250.00.

The new school-house of the dimensions above described would cost, owing to the high price of lumber and other materials, painting, etc., $2000.00, including benches, etc.

As the Department in its letter of last month referring to the subject of building suggests that the band pass a resolution of the council "if it is possible", to the effect that it should itself provide the necessary funds to erect this large school-house, we regret to be obliged to say that it is impossible to pass this resolution for two reasons, (1) because, our funds being very limited, this school-house would take "more than half" of our capital, (2) because the Protestants of the tribe would be opposed to it.

Wherefore your humble wards respectfully pray Your Excellency to permit them to say that they regret very much to find themselves thus always refused in their appeals for assistance, in their great necessities, even in their misfortunes such as the burning of their church, the rebuilding of their old presbytery, and new their school-house.

That the Roman Catholic school-house, although so well attended, must remain in need and suffering, if a parliamentary grant ($1500.00) is not allowed.

That in their humble opinion your wards claim that the Abenakis furnish to the "public treasury" a good deal of money "having to buy everything" like all the other subjects of the Empire, since "the good presents" of former times have been discontinued to them, and all their
hunting grounds sold.

That not having been able to get any assistance to build their presbytery—a favour that the Iroquois "who scalped the whites" were able to obtain ($1000.00) to rebuild the old presbytery of Father Charlevoix—the Abenakis, left to their own resources for five years, have not yet been able to make the same habitable.

That even their church burnt in 1900 is not yet finished, and debts having been contracted, the interest is accumulating. Nevertheless the Amalecite Indians have been able to get assistance, like the Iroquois.

The schools of Upper Canada and of Manitoba are also abundantly provided with annual assistance at the expense of the government, which also maintains ours, but that a parliamentary grant, or out of some other public fund, $1500.00 is still imperatively necessary this year for the Roman Catholic school for the Abenakis of St. Francis, which they respectfully solicit from the government of Your Excellency.

The whole humbly submitted.

OTTAWA, 24th April, 1902

The Secretary:

With reference to the petition hereunder from the priest, chief and councillors of the Abenakis Band of St Francis, addressed to His Excellency, the Governor General, asking for a grant of $1500.00 for the erection of a new schoolhouse on their reserve, I beg to say that there is no doubt that the present school building is much too small for the number of school children on the reserve. The enrolment has reached 65 with an average attendance of from 50 to 55, while the seating accommodation of the present building is not sufficient for anything like that number, to say nothing of the lack of air space.

I may also remark that it is utterly impossible for one teacher to give anything like proper attention to so many pupils, who are graded all the way up to the 5th standard. In Ontario 45 is the maximum allowed any one teacher, even when they are all in the one standard.

Both Mr Inspector Macrae, the Public School Inspector and the Agent have called the Department's attention to the necessity for enlarged school premises. No addition could be made to the present building as the lot on which it stands is not large enough. There is no doubt as to the need of a new school, - the only question is that of funds. It is
too late for any appropriation to be made this year if the Department were willing to do so. These Indians have nearly $4000.00 to their credit and I do not see that they could do better than use a portion of their capital in putting up a proper schoolhouse, when the Department might undertake to pay a second teacher.

The Law Clerk informs me that it will be necessary to obtain the consent of the Band before any portion of their capital could be used for this purpose and in February last Agent Comire was requested to submit the question of using a portion of their funds for this purpose, to the Band and obtain their consent if possible by resolution in council for the expenditure of the necessary funds.

In the petition hereunder, above referred to, on page 2 you will see that the petitioners regret to say that it is impossible to pass this resolution for two reasons:- First because their funds being very limited, the schoolhouse would take more than half their capital; Second, because the Protestants of the tribe would be opposed to it.

I am still of the opinion that it would better for these Indians to spend their money in the manner indicated than as they are now doing, in legal and travelling expenses and as they are well to do, it would entail no hardship on them. They would however, apparently prefer to receive the money as a gift, as wards of the Department, basing their claim
claim upon what it has done for other Bands.

This is how the case stands and if the Indians will not consent to the necessary expenditure they must, by so doing, expect to force the Department to put up a new building, as otherwise the children will suffer.

Sir,

Now that we have succeeded in becoming unanimous on the question of the school, and as the chief and all the Protestant councillors as well as Roman Catholic have signed before me the resolution approving of the contract for the school between Frederick R. Obomsawin, Abenakis carpenter, and the band, it is very important that we should receive the money mentioned in the contract as soon as possible.

The contractor is to hand over the school on the 1st or 15th September, and if he is delayed, even a little, we shall not have our school by that time. It is necessary that he should be given a portion of the money to buy materials. That is why I consider that it is very important that our Agent should be in possession of the money very soon.

I congratulate you heartily on your last letter authorizing the band to take $1500 out of its funds. All the Abenakis understood your desire, and I have never before seen such good feeling in the tribe.

As I have been appointed overseer of the work, I can assure you that I have succeeded in getting the finest piece of land possible for this building on the bank of the river, and that the contractor, Frederick Obomsawin, is believed to be the best workman in the township. I had him to build the presbytery and the church, and I certify that he gave thorough satisfaction. His only fault is that he is poor; he needs money in proportion as he works. That is why I ask you to let us have the money very soon.
Please depend upon it that I shall take care that the plan is followed, and believe me with sincerity.

Yours very truly,

Jos. deGonzague, Priest,
Missionary.

Sir,

I received here a letter from Mr. Field, Missionary to the Cree Indians, in the Edmonton Road. He states that he will have his school house ready this fall, so he supposes opening school for September. The Department has not thought much matter its way—no plan made in the meantime. It seems to require a great amount of planning, sketches, and studies, etc., to make things work properly. The people who remain in their lodges and able to act at any time of the year, and do not hesitate, hurry.
having only three months in the year to earn our living in this sparse country far from our homes.

Knowing all that and the vast necessity to have the school more fitted for the next September school term, and as the new house should be large enough, we are now so worried that when it is raining they have to use pails & tins to receive the rain water coming through the roof. The upper floor, where some of the pupils have to sleep away their coats owing to rain seeping through the roof.

For the construction of this new school house we have been by resolution of the Council appointed to oversee the Rev. Mr. Symonds so that every thing may be completed & made right. The Rev. Missionary having conducted so well the members of the church was the presiding
The committee meeting.

We have, so well understood all the particulars of the construction of said schoolhouse, directed by the heads sisters & Mr. Thomas who has charge of said school, that we, the chiefs, missionary and the agent have found that said Rev. Thomas can be paid to finish all that building—a two-story house 30 x 40, with stairs and every thing will painted, after $1500, was surely not too high.
rather cheap, but as he lives in our village, 1/4 mile from the place where the house is to be built, he can better afford to build it at that price than anyone else, having the right to take some lumber on the Reserve without buying it, I mean some big lumber, one time that will take to pay for tenders, after the plans have been examined and all submitted & the Department wait for the final correspondences, would take a minute time to build the house itself. To the Secretary—

The Plans made by Frederick Obansawin for the new Roman Catholic Schoolhouse on the Pierreville Reserve, together with the Specifications, are in my opinion quite sufficient for the information of the Department, and for the guidance of the Builder.

The Plans are for a frame building two stories high, with a stone basement or cellar. The roof is covered with galvanized iron, and finished with a neat cupola. The details of the construction of the building as shewn in the Specifications, are for a frame house of first class construction.

The Indian Council, the Agent and the Missionary, who it appears, has been appointed by the Council to oversee the work, are very anxious that it should be given to the said Obansawin.

Obansawin offers to do the work for $1300.00. I can confidently state that this is a very low price and that nothing would be gained by asking for Tenders from other parties.

There is no objection, I believe, to the Missionary acting as Superintendent of the work, for, and responsible to, the Indian Council only. The Agent, however, I think, should superintend the work in the interest of the Dept.

Moreover, there is nothing to fear: the Agent will only pay for the work in proportion as it progresses. Then I promise to superintend the work and not to run any risks. Agent Comire and I will, therefore, be the best guarantee that the work of this school-house will be brought to a good termination.

I submitted the specification of this school-house to His Lordship the Bishop of Nicolets, and His Lordship begs you, with me, to be kind enough to send us the $1000 that is due us as soon as possible, in order that we may go on with and hand over the school-house for our children next September. It is of the greatest importance that this school-house should be built at once. I hope, therefore, that you will not delay any more, and that this good understanding with the Abenakis in regard to this important question will be crowned with success by the promptitude with which you will hand over to us what you have voted, namely, the $1000, which we beg you to send us as soon as possible.

General assembly of the Abenakis Band of St. Francois de Sales held in the Council-house Friday, the fourteenth day of the month of November, 1902, at ten o'clock in the morning, at which meeting were present:

Joseph Laurent, Chief
Thomas Msadoquis, Councillor
Louis Watso,
Nicolas Panadis,
Pierre Emmett,
Rev. Jos. de Gonzaque, Catholic Missionary
A. O. Comire, Agent.

and a great number of other members of the band.

The Chief Joseph Laurent reported to the meeting that the new Catholic School-house of the Abenakis Village is almost entirely finished, according to the plans and estimate adopted last spring, but that there are still certain things which have been forgotten and which were not provided for in the plans and estimate, and which are absolutely necessary to do to complete the said school-house, such as, for example, the installation of a system of hot air heating, the construction of cupboards in the walls to store the linen, closets, etc., and to arrive at this end it will be necessary to vote the sum of $250.00, the balance not yet used of the sum of $1600.00 offered by the Department in its letter No. 152,859-5, dated the 26th April last.

The Rev. Joseph de Gonzaque also made an eloquent speech in support of the proposition of Chief Joseph Laurent.

It was then proposed by Louis Watso, seconded by Thomas Msadoquis:

That the meeting adjourn until two o'clock P.M.

Unanimously adopted.

The meeting was reopened at two o'clock in the afternoon.

It was then proposed by Chief Joseph Laurent, seconded by Councillor Thomas Msadoquis:

That, considering the representations and facts heretofore mentioned, it is proposed to finish and complete the said school-house so as to be able to install the Rev. Sisters to teach there and to reside there as teachers.
That it should be asked, as it is by the present asked that the sum of two hundred and fifty dollars be taken from the Capital Funds of the band in accordance with the offer made by the Department in its letter No. 152,859--5 dated the 26th April last, or from the Interest Funds, if they are enough, and that the Governor General be respectfully asked to give his consent to this end.

Proposed in amendment by Councillor Louis Watson, seconded by H. L. Masta:

That in view of the capital and interest belonging equally to the Protestants and the Catholics, the proportion of these moneys belonging to the Protestants be reserved to defray the expenses of their school-house, that is, the sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) if the sum of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) is granted to the Catholics, as above asked.

The Protestants require three hundred and twenty-five dollars ($325.00), or less, to purchase land to transplant their school-house to a more central place, for the repair of the said school-house and in time and when the occasion arrives the Department of Indian Affairs will submit the plans and specifications and estimates of these works.

In all cases they ask for their fourth part of these moneys and for the purpose above mentioned.

Proposed in further amendment by Chief Joseph Laurent, seconded by Councillor Nicolas Panadis:

That the Catholic officers having already consented at the meeting of the 15th May last to the request of the Protestants, namely, to take the sum of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) from the Capital Funds before presenting them with any estimation of the supposed needs of their school-house, we consider that the present request for another sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) is too premature inasmuch as the two hundred and fifty dollars are not yet expended for the purposes which were set forth to the Council in May last, that not a single cent's worth of construction having yet been made by the Protestants it is
is altogether illogical to ask an additional seventy-five dollars ($75.00) simply on account of presumptive needs.

That in support of the principal motion Section 76, sub-Section G of the Indian Act should be considered by the Department.

Objection made by Louis Watso, Councillor, that this amendment be not accepted, as it does not bear on the amendment.

The Agent allowed the amendment as everyone who wishes can make an amendment.

Proposed in amendment to the amendment, by H. L. Masta, seconded by Samuel Watso:

That, as the Catholics in May last consented to the expenditure of two hundred and fifty dollars for the Protestant School inasmuch as the Protestants on their part consented to the expenditure of one thousand dollars for the Catholic School;

As the Catholics now ask another grant of two hundred and fifty dollars for their school, the Protestants give their consent under the condition that they also be granted the sum of seventy-five dollars for their school;

Whereas in the absence of the principals they have not had the time to give the plans, specifications and estimates for the work which they want to have done to their school-house, but that they are at present in a position to furnish them approximately.

Whereas the Protestants only ask for their fourth part of these moneys and for commendable ends this Council is of opinion that to do them justice it is well to grant them this that they wish, the same as to the Catholics.

Abenakis Mission, 18th Nov., 1902.

Mr. J. D. McLean,
Secretary.

Sir:

The Indian Department last spring sanctioned the resolution of the Council of the band appointing me together with the Agent to oversee the works in connection with the new Abenakis School. It is my duty to certify to you now that the building is finished, that the works have been done according to the plans and estimates which were submitted for your approbation, that these works have been scrupulously surveyed by Mr. Agent Comire and by me, that the house is ready to be given over by the contractor, that the latter is not willing to hand over this building before having received the sum which was given him for the contract, namely, $1300.0

that a Council meeting was held this week by the Chief and Councillors of the tribe before the assembled band, that the resolution asking a surplus of $250.00 from the Government to complete the extra works absolutely necessary to the new school was signed by the Chiefs and Councillors with the exception of one. I also certify that these extras cannot be delayed without great inconvenience inasmuch as we will not be able to install our Sisters and their pupils without this being done; that the band in general desire that these moneys be granted as soon as possible and the $250.00 be taken from the band funds. Councillor Watzo proposed to the Council of the band to pass a resolution asking the Government for an additional sum of $75.00 to the $250.00 granted last spring for the Protestant School. It was objected to by the Chief and by me that a single cent of the $250.00 had not yet been expended and consequently they might do with the first grant, it appears premature to ask for a second without knowing what they
they are going to do with these moneys. We are in urgent need, said the Chief, we must finish our school and we have no more money; you others, you still have your money and you have no further need before beginning your works. Begin your works and if you have not enough to finish it I promise to give you all my assistance in time and place to complete your works. I made the same remarks to the band; this appears to me to very logical. Your authority will allow us to do what we want but the main thing is that you allow our Agent to have the $1250.00 as soon as possible in order that the house may be given over to us and that our children may enter therein.

I have also to say that in asking for the extra $80.00 we have forgotten to mention the transport of a shed which blocks the pupils' passage; this shed should be removed. The Chief has asked me to inform you that this will cost another twenty dollars, which will make $100.00 of an extra. I can promise, in short, that when we have executed these extra works we will have one of the most spacious schools in the county of Yamaska. The Member for the County publicly said the day before yesterday at a banquet presided over by the Bishop of Nicolet: "The Government at Ottawa gives in the Abenakis an example of devotion and interest which we should have for the education of our children," after which the speaker finished his speech by congratulating the Government, the Bishop of Nicolet and the Abenakis.

The Government has given the true impulse towards good and the work which it has authorized does it honour. I hope that it will immediately give us the means to finish it sooner by sending us the moneys which we have asked it for.

With consideration,

Your, etc.,

Jos. de Gonzalez, Miss.Priest.

P.S.- As to the question of the widow Glaude, who took possession of her house after we had bought it by contract, we are waiting for the Hon. Superintendent to designate someone authorized to make her vacate it so that we can sell it immediately and realize some money, which will assist us in paying the $1300.00. Your, etc., Jos. de G., Miss. Priest.

We, the undersigned Chief and Councillors of the Abenakis of St. Francois beg to draw your attention to the following:

The contractor for the school-house has finished his contract for $1300.00, but, as he had the assurance of Axx, which has voted for this purpose, there remains $300.00 for him to get in order that the tribe can have the building handed over to it.

The Reverend Sisters,- the teachers, having shown the necessity for certain additions to the house to the amount of $80.00; a furnace having been placed in it for the heating of all the building at a cost of $60.00; $130.00 for land--- all these things being over and above the cost of building, according to the plan and estimates furnished by Mr. F. Obumsawin, it follows that the total for things indispensable, or at any rate in the highest degree necessary, as we decided in Council in the presence of the Agent Mr. Comire and the Rev. Jos. DeGonzague, will mount up to $270.00, which, added to the $300.00 to complete the $1300.00, will make $570.00. The Council of chiefs by virtue of Section 76 of the Indian Act, 1856, sub-Section (c) therefore decided by resolution of the Council, Councillor Louis Watso being the only one opposed, to draw from our capital funds or interest if there is enough, to complete the payment of all that is necessary for this school-house. This makes in all $1250.00 instead of $1500.00, which was asked for at first and which the Department was satisfied to give from our funds.

On examining all these figures the Department will find that $220.00 will be realized by the sale of the school-house which will be made when the Sisters leave it. Again, the $1300.00 contract,- the $130.00 for land,- the hot air furnace for $60.00, and the slight additions in the interior and the others to the exterior, as well as the water
water-closets at a cost of $80.00--- will all be paid for by
the result of the sale of the house and the $1250.00 taken
from our funds.

Hoping that the Department, which was so good as
to encourage the building under the Rev. Missionary and A-
gent's oversight, will be satisfied with all that our Council
has done in this regard so that the Rev. lady teachers and
the numerous pupils which they have may be placed there soon,
these $250.00 should be sent to the Agent with the least
possible delay.

In awaiting this favour,

We have the honour to be, Sir,

Your humble servants,

Sir,

As the Dept. gave me the charge of superintending the erection of the new school-house for the Abenakis last Summer, and as the council of the band also selected me for the same purpose, I have discharged this duty in such a manner as to bring the matter to a good conclusion, and it was I who looked after matters along with the contractor, Frederick R. Obumsawin, through the whole contract. It was I also, with Chief Laurent, who purchased the land from the Widow Claude; in fact it was I that saw to and managed everything until the entrance of the pupils into the new school-house. All that being known to the Agent and to the Dept., there still remains $280 due the contractor, $150 having been taken out of the $1250 voted by the band and paid by the Government.

Now we have the old Roman Catholic school-house which if sold might bring in, I suppose, between $150 and $200. There is also the little cottage of the Widow Claude which we purchased with the land in accordance with the agreement. This little house would be worth about $50.

Now as the contractor is beginning, and properly, to turn to me with his requests for payment of the balance of $280 that is coming to him, will the Dept. have sufficient confidence in me again, to allow me, myself, to look at these two old houses? If I had nothing to do with this charge, and it were agreed to sell these houses...
on credit, payment not to be made till the Fall, I beg
to say that I should not be in favor of such a thing; it
would place me in a bad position, the contractor would
press me harder; I require ready money to pay the con-
tractor, who is a poor man. Besides, I regret to say that
credit in the band is always difficult to collect, es-
pecially mine, for the debtors count on the fact that I
will not take them before the courts.

I ask you therefore authority to sell these
houses, and I hope to be able to find the money due Fred-
erick Obumsawin. An immediate reply will oblige yours
very truly

Jos. de Gonzaque, priest,
Missionary.

Sir,

In reply to your letter No. 152859/6A, of the 7th inst., I have to remark as follows:

A lightning rod on the R.C. school-building appeared to the chiefs to be absolutely necessary, and also to the missionary and myself, because it is not yet three years since the R.C. church in the village was completely destroyed by a fire caused by lightning. It was only after sacrifices of all kinds that we succeeded in re-building it, and there is still a debt of $1500 on the church.

We do not wish to expose the school, which cost about $3,000, to a similar disaster through the same negligence that caused the loss of the church, for the small expense of $21 for a lightning-rod system.

It is true that this expense was not authorized by the Dept., but the matter was urgent, and we counted upon the Department's approving of this expense, and the chiefs did not hesitate to authorize the same out of their interest funds, inasmuch as it was a case of absolute necessity.

We are very much astonished to hear you say that the benefit of a lightning rod on the building is doubtful, when this is something acknowledged by all scientific men. After these explanations we are confident that the Dept. will no longer hesitate to pay this account.

Your obedient servant,

A.O. Comire,

Il y aurait certaines réparations qu'il serait urgent de faire faire à la maison d'école catholique du village des Abénaquis; ce serait de faire charroyer de la terre autour du selage pour la renforcer, afin de faciliter l'évacuation des eaux au printemps et empêcher éboulement du sable, comme cela est arrivé le printemps dernier; cela servirait aussi à rendre la maison plus chaude et empêcherait le selage de se détériorer par la gelée; dans le même but de rendre la maison plus chaude, il y aurait aussi une autre petite réparation à faire dans la cave, où il faudrait mettre environ deux rangs de briques par-dessus la selage pour empêcher l'air de pénétrer entre les lambris, ce qui refroidit beaucoup la maison.

L'hiver dernier, le chauffage a coûté très cher, il a fallu dépenser beaucoup de bois, et la maison a été très froide tout l'hiver.

Le coût des réparations dont je veux parler, serait d'environ $12.00 et serait plus que compensé par l'économie faite sur le chauffage.

Sir,

Certain repairs are urgently required to be made to the Roman Catholic school-house in the Abenakis village: there will be the carting of the earth around the foundation to bank it up, in order to facilitate the draining of water in spring and to prevent the slipping away of the sand as happened last spring; this will also make the house warmer and will prevent the foundation from becoming deteriorated by the frost. With the same object of making the house warmer, there will also be another small repair necessary to be made in the cellar, where about two rows of brick will have to be placed above the foundation to prevent the air from coming through the wainscoting, which helps very much to make the house cold. Last winter fuel was very dear, it was necessary to use a great deal of wood, and the house was very cold all winter.

The cost of the repairs mentioned will be about $12, and will be more than compensated by the saving of fuel.

Please tell me whether you authorize me to have these repairs made.

Abenakis Agency,
St. Francois du Lac, 29th November, 1904.

The Secretary
of the Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:

I have written you sometime ago with regard to certain repairs to be made to the Catholic School of the Abenakis Village, and by your reply No. 152859...5 dated the 27th October last you gave permission to have the repairs asked for made to the amount of $12.00; but the Chiefs of the band after having had the works to be done examined by a workman found that the amount at first asked for would not be sufficient and that it would require about $20.00.

Moreover there are no ventilators in the classes and you know as well as I do that it is very important for the children's health that there should be; this will cost about $10.00 more.

I inclose you herewith an authorization signed by the Chiefs to take this amount from their funds. Be good enough to inform me if the Department will allow the above mentioned repairs to be made.

Your obedient servant,

A. O. Comire,
Agent.
Exq.

Ottawa, 3rd December, 1904.

Sir,

In view of the receipt in your letter of the 29th ultimo with enclosure I have to say that the department approves of an expenditure not exceeding $30.00 being incurred in having the necessary repairs made to the Roman Catholic School at Abenakia Village.

Yours obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Secretary.

A. O. Conrath, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Francois du Lac, P.Q.

Sir,

I transmit herewith an account for $14.50 in favour of Rev. Sister Woods, Mother Superior of the Abenakis convent; this account was incurred in painting the floors of the class rooms, which was necessary, for they were in great need of it.

This work was done during the holidays last summer, in order that all would be ready for the opening of the school in autumn.

In this connection permit me to remark to the Dept. that since there have been resident Sisters on the reserve very marked progress has been made in the education of the children; so much so that this winter we were able to assist at a dramatic and musical entertainment, where the different roles were ably filled and in which only Indian children took part.

I would take advantage also to ask the Dept. to grant the request of the R.C. school for a typewriter, which has already been made of it; it would be a great advantage to these children to be able to learn to use it, which the Sisters are would be pleased to attend to.

Your obedient Servant,

Sir,

I transmit you herewith an account for $21 in favour of the Rev. Joseph de Gonzague, approved by the chief and councillors, for books purchased during the holidays for the R.C. school in the St. Francois Village.

Abenakis Agency,
St. François du Lac, 6th November, 1905.

The Secretary of the Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:

As winter is coming on there are certain repairs necessary to be made to the Catholic School of the First Abenakis Village. A double door is required at the main entrance of the School, which will cost, placing and painting—about $8.00. There are also required three outside shutters to the windows of the dormitory which will cost about $1.00 each—a total of $3.00. Lastly water-closets are required for the children. This small building should have two doors, and should be 8 feet by 4 feet. This will cost wainscotted (clapboarded) painted and covered with sheet-iron, about $25.00.

The Secretary,
Dept. of I.A.,
Ottawa,

Sir,-

It is necessary that some repairs should be made to the closets and to the drain at the R.C. school in the Abenakis village before the opening of the classes next fall.

It is necessary to renew the drain, which is made of wood; it is too small and becomes choked up every winter; it should be replaced by a six-inch drain pipe; the drain is about fifty feet long and would cost including putting down from $15.00 to $16.00.

It is also necessary to repair the closets. This will cost from $12.00 to $13.00.

It is also necessary to raise the wood shed and to make a place for coal; this will cost about $10.00.

Please tell me whether you authorize me to have these things done, for advantage ought to be taken of the vacation time to have the work done, and it is absolutely necessary.

Yours, etc.,

A.O. Comire,
I. A.

The heating apparatus of the R.C. school in the Abenakis village, which at the time of the building of the school-house, for want of money, was made to consist of an old stove, walled in, in the cellar, is now beginning to deteriorate and threatens to go into ruins. The old stove is broken, the masonry is falling apart and so no longer gives satisfaction and is dangerous for fire.

The Reverend Sisters, who occupy the school-house, ask, and properly so, to have the heating apparatus renewed. I got a mechanic to go and look at it, and he states that it is absolutely necessary to have another next winter.

The following are the lowest rates that I could obtain:

For the McClary Sunshine furnace, with a capacity sufficient to heat the school, all placed ready to heat, $150; for a Kelsey furnace, James Smart, maker, which is said to be superior, already to heat, $190; these prices include everything, the pipes, work, etc.

Now it is probable that the band will not consent that this amount be taken out of its funds which are already too small. Nevertheless these repairs are very necessary. Please tell me whether the Dept. authorizes me to have the work done.

Please tell me also what the Dept. has decided in regard to desks for the school, in regard to which I wrote you some time ago.

Your, &c.,

A.O. Comire,
I. A.

Ottawa, August 29, 1907.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Mr. Agent Comire reports that the Roman Catholic school in the Abenakis village requires a new furnace, the one in use being completely worn out.

He says that a McClary Sunshine furnace can be installed for $150.00, while a Kelsey furnace, made by the James Smart Manufacturing Co., would cost $190. The Kelsey is said to be the best. Both these offers include everything, radiators, work, etc., and as the school vote will not stand this outlay, I would suggest that it be charged against the funds of the band under authority given by the Order in Council of Sept. 1, 1901, on file 109950, which provides that such articles as new desks, seats, stoves, stovepipes and blackboards may be charged against the capital of the band on whose reserve the school is situated, instead of, in every case when such expenditure is necessary, reporting the matter to His Excellency in Council and obtaining special authority.

The best would be the cheapest, and I would suggest that the Agent be authorized to close with the offer of the Smart Manufacturing Co., as a furnace should be installed at once.

Sir,

Permit me again to ask your attention to the question of the enlargement of the convent of the Abenakis of Pierreville.

There are two things at present of which the band is greatly in need, namely, a good public hall and the enlargement of the convent. If it is possible to have both, so much the better; but if on account of the small amount of funds of the band choice has to be made between the two, what is most pressing at the moment is the enlargement of the convent, which is now too small for present requirements.

If the Department could come to our assistance for a certain amount, as it has already done for the industrial schools in the West, that would be of great help to us; but if we have to count only on the funds of the band for this work, it will be impossible to do all this work at the present time, and it will be necessary to put it aside for a little time and to do only what is the most pressing now what is the most pressing, as I said above, is the enlargement of the convent. Perhaps later on, if the reserve at Lake St. John is valuable and the band can sell it to advantage, it will be possible to do what cannot be done today unless the Department finds the means to assist us in some manner.
Monsieur,

Permettez-moi d'attirer de nouveau votre attention sur la question de l'agrandissement du couvent des Abénaquis de Pierreville.

Il y a actuellement deux choses dont la bande a grandement besoin, savoir : une bonne maison publique et l'agrandissement du couvent.

S'il est possible d'avoir les deux, c'est tant mieux ; mais si, à cause du montant peu élevé des fonds de la bande, il faille choisir entre les deux, ce qui presse le plus dans le moment c'est l'agrandissement du couvent, qui est actuellement trop petit pour répondre aux besoins qui font sentir.

Si le Département pouvait nous venir en aide, pour un certain montant, comme il l'a déjà fait pour les écoles trielles de l'Ouest, cela nous serait d'un grand secours, mais s'il nous faut compter seulement sur les fonds de la bande pour ces travaux, il est impossible de pouvoir à présent tous ces travaux là, et il va falloir nécessairement en laisser un peu de côté, et ne faire que ce qui est le plus pressant ; or ce qui presse le plus, dit plus haut, c'est l'agrandissement du...

Ottawa, August 25, 1908.

Sir,

The Department proposes to build an addition to the Roman Catholic School on the Pierreville reserve, and it has decided to have the work done by day labour under your superintendence. Plans and specifications are now in the office of Dr. A.O. Comire, Indian Agent, at St. Francois du Lac, and he will be asked to hand them over to you.

The Department wishes this work to be commenced at once so that it may be completed before the winter sets in, and you are hereby authorized to purchase all the necessary material and engage the tradesmen and labourers needed in carrying out the work. Advances will be made from time to time for the payment of wages on receipt of duplicate pay-sheets certified by you. The merchants from whom you purchase supplies should furnish accounts in duplicate, which should be forwarded to the Department bearing your certificate that the materials have been supplied and the prices are fair and just.

You will be good enough to report progress of the work from time to time, when further instructions

D. Chene, Esq., C.E.,
Ottawa.
will be given you. The Department would like you to return one set of the plans and specifications which you will receive from the Agent. Your remuneration will be at the rate of $4.00 per day and reasonable expenses.

Your obedient Servant,

J.D. McLean

Secretary.
Ottawa, August 31, 1909.

Sir,

Referring to official letter of the 11th inst., I beg to say that the offers submitted by you for the proposed addition to the Roman Catholic school building on the Pierreville reserve are so far in advance of the estimated cost of the work that the Department has decided to make the addition by day labour, and it has instructed Mr. D. Chene to proceed to Pierreville and make the necessary arrangements for commencing the work and carrying it to completion.

The Department would, therefore, like you to let Mr. Chene have the two copies of the plans and specifications which were sent you on the 11th inst. and afford him any assistance he may require. Be good enough to advise the contractors that their offers have not been accepted.

Your obedient Servant,

A.O. Comire, Esq., M.D.,
Indian Agent,
St. Francois du Lac, Que.

Referring to your letter of Aug.11, No.152859-5, I submitted, as requested, the plans of the annex to the Roman Catholic Abenakis school to contractors of the neighbourhood. Sir,

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th inst., reporting that you are unable to procure stone sills of the quality mentioned in the specifications for the addition to the St. Joseph's Convent and asking that you be allowed to substitute wooden sills.

In reply I beg to say that the Department would like you to make enquiries as to whether suitable stone sills could not be purchased in some of the neighboring towns. If not, they could be had at Sorel or Montreal at from 50 to 55 cents per foot. If they can be obtained at this price, they may be bought and shipped to Pierreville.

Details of the stairway for the building are inclosed.

Sir,

As I have not yet received a reply to my proposal for lighting and for the changes in material which I am anxious to hear about. I would like to add that the Sisters here have no servant and tell me that the only help in the school cannot be trusted for taking care of an acetylene generator, consequently accidents might result. The Missionary here tells me that he would be willing to have the apparatus with a meter in his residence, which is but a few feet from the school and would take care of it himself and pay his share of lighting as indicated by the meter. He would also pay the expense for pipes from his place to the school.

I think this a very advantageous proposal and worthy of being considered by the Department the only cost for the Department being the purchase of the machine and pipes; the placing of pipes in the school. No additional cost would be necessitated for the care of it.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient Servant,

Ottawa, April 16, 1915.

Memorandum

Rev. Sister Blandine, Superior at the St. Joseph's Academy, Pierreville, has requested me to ask the Department whether it would be possible to have the proposed hot-water heating-system installed in the building before the summer holidays.

As the teachers are leaving the school in the first days of July to attend a Mission in the City, they would not like to leave the building in the hands of steam-fitters and other labourers.

The amount of radiation necessary for this new heating-system has been figured and the work can be started next month if authorized.
St. Joseph Academy
Pierreville, May 12, 1915.

Honorable Duncan C. Scott,
Ottawa

Honorable Sir,

Please accept our grateful thanks for the Hot Water Heating Apparatus granted us by the intervention of Mr. Chené.

This gentleman has come to visit us this morning to see what has to be done, so as to begin the work as soon as possible.
We would wish the work to be completed towards the end of our summer holidays.

We have heard that you are coming to Pierreville next Fall. You would be most welcome at the sound of the Abenakis Band.

The tribe is very musically gifted.

Expecting the pleasure and honor of your visit, I say once more: Many, many thanks!

Believe me, honorable Sir,

Your most humble servant,

Sr. St. Blandine,
Principal.

Ottawa, June 7, 1915.

Memorandum.

Mr. Scott,

As no local steam-fitters were available at Pierreville to install the hot water heating system at the School Convent there, it has been suggested by Mr. Mondou that this part of the work be given to Mr. A. Blondin & Co., of St. Hyacinthe, Que., who are known as reliable contractors, and, therefore, strongly recommended by Mr. Mondou and the Sisters in charge of the school.

Mr. Blondin offers to furnish the tools and necessary labour to install the heating system as per plans and specifications which I have prepared, for the sum of $275.00, being much less than my estimate and prices given to me by other contractors in Montreal and Ottawa which varied from $500.00 to $700.00.

I presume that it would be rather difficult for a contractor who pays Union wages, to perform the proposed work for an amount less than $550.00. It is for this reason that
there is such a large difference in the prices which were given me.

If it is your wish that this portion of the work be done by contract, I would recommend that Mr. Blondin's offer be accepted now that all the materials are delivered and the building ready for the work to be started.

March 8, 1923.

Dr. Scott,

There is at the Pierreville School Convent a cast iron sectional horizontal boiler, which was purchased in 1916 at a price of £200.00. This boiler has since been replaced by two vertical round boilers in order to save money in fuel. Three years ago various dealers in boilers were requested to make an offer for the old boiler, but none was made. The sections of this boiler are now in the fuel room in the basement and are a nuisance to the caretaker.

Mr. Hamilton, lumber and steamfitter, who had charge of the installation of the new boilers and knew about the old ones being for sale, called at this office the other day with one of his clients and made an offer of £75.00 against my estimate of £100.00 for the boiler. We finally came to an agreement of a price of £90.00, the understanding being that they are to take the boiler in its actual condition whether damaged or not at the building, and without further expense to the Department. As it is not probable that a better offer will be made, I beg to recommend that their price be accepted and that the agent be requested to have it loaded on the freight as soon as he is supplied with the necessary amount to pay for this work. I shall also arrange to have the price of the boiler paid to this Department before it leaves Pierreville.

Ottawa, May 3rd, 1928.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 24th ultimo, enclosing a communication from Rev. Sister Josephine, Superior of St. Joseph's Academy, Ouanak, in which she requests that the land recently acquired for the use of this school be cleaned, levelled and fenced, in order that it can be used as a playground for the pupils. You have already been requested to forward a report and estimate of the cost of having this work done. This matter should receive your prompt attention.

With reference to the request to have the water boiler, now in the kitchen, installed near the furnace in the cellar, so that during winter the water can be heated by the furnace and in summer by electricity, I shall also be pleased to have a report from you as to the cost involved in having this change made.

You may arrange to have the cellar stair, which was damaged by the removal of the furnace, repaired and placed in good condition. No unnecessary expense should be incurred in this work, and you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Relative to the providing of a grant to purchase prizes for the pupils at the end of the present school year, I beg to say that you may incur an expenditure not exceeding the amount of $20. Please consult the Rev. Principal as to the supplies she requires, and after the prizes have been purchased, you should forward an itemized account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

A. E. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, giving an estimate of the cost of supplying a new hot water boiler and installing same in the cellar, near the furnace, at the St. Joseph's Academy, Odanak, so that during winter the water can be heated by the furnace and in summer by electricity.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a communication from Rev. Sister Mary Josephine, Superior of the Abenakis School Convent, requesting that some drainage work and other repairs be carried out to the school grounds. I would ask you to kindly arrange to have the following work performed as early as weather conditions will permit and as economically as possible, under your supervision.

Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Minister of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I am informed that the Sisters of Odanak are applying to your Department for the supply of an electric refrigerator for their establishment as well as for an electric washing machine and wringer.

I would be much obliged if you could grant the request of those good Sisters. I have ascertained myself that their request is justified. The process of cooling by electricity is hygienic and cannot be compared with the present system of refrigerator which offers many disadvantages with regard to sanitation.

Moreover, the Sisters have a great deal of washing to do and it is a painful sight to see them doing this work without using the improved methods and get the benefit of electric machines.

I would appreciate as a high favour whatever you can do to meet with the wishes of those good Sisters.

Yours very truly,

Condensing Units

Electric or automatic refrigeration is produced by pumping a liquid, which vaporizes at a very low temperature, from a reservoir into the cooling unit set within the refrigerator, where it vaporizes and absorbs heat—after which the heat-laden vapor is withdrawn, placed under pressure and cooled, whereupon it returns to liquid form and flows back into the reservoir to be used over again. Thus cold is produced in the refrigerator by removing heat.

The entire unit which does the pumping is known as a condensing unit. It is operated by an electrically driven motor, thermostatically controlled. When the temperature in the refrigerator rises to between 45° and 50°, the pump is automatically started and continues work until temperature has been reduced to a predetermined level, when it automatically stops.

This is the "heart" of any refrigeration system. An enviable reputation has been established by the superior performance of Copeland Condensing units. Evolution of the Frigidaire Compressor

The Frigidaire compressor has progressed from a completely-sealed type to the present model which permits easy access to all parts. Frigidaire engineers adapted the cast-iron dome seal originally, basing their design upon early discoveries. Progress from that type is the result of more than 16 years of research and experience in hundreds of thousands of homes.

When the AB Compressor was designed, engineers moved the float valve to the cooling unit, where it became more easily accessible and operated under a low pressure. Flare nuts were added to the lines, making the connections simpler.

More complete accessibility was the feature when the A Compressor was designed. By dividing the compressor, condenser and receiver, any of these parts may be adjusted without disassembling the others. The drive was also made easy to reach by supplanting the inaccessible direct-gear drive with the belt drive.

Valves were added to both the cooling coil and the B Compressor, permitting basement installations. Other valves were installed in the lines, and filter screens were placed in the copper tubing where they could be reached for cleaning. Piston valves were installed to reduce the running time.

The early Model A Compressor had the float valve in the compressor unit where it was under a high pressure. All the compressor parts, with the exception of the motor, were encased under one dome. Even the copper tubing was sealed by soldering.
Evolution of the Frigidaire Cooling Unit

The evolution of the Frigidaire cooling coil unit from the brine tank to copper-finned coil is an interesting study in engineering advancement. The brine tank was first used in cold-storage plants and it was natural that the first automatic refrigerating mechanisms should reflect this practice by the use of the brine tank in the cooling compartment of the refrigerator.

The early Model A cooling unit consisted of a brine tank, holding a large quantity of brine, in which only a few coils were placed.

When the Model B cooling unit was designed, the number of coils was increased, with a corresponding decrease in the quantity of brine.

The brine tank was then eliminated, leaving only the coils. This cooling unit assures simpler, more sensitive temperature control than the brine tank.

The present copper-finned cooling unit is the result of more than 16 years' experience in automatic refrigeration. This type has greater surface area, which increases its operating efficiency. It can be operated at a higher average coil temperature and at the same time maintains the low box temperature required. It is the most economical coil for installations using this type of coil.

Ottawa, June 6, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd ultimo, enclosing a communication from the Rev. Sister Superior of the St. Joseph's Academy, in which she requests a grant of $20 to purchase prizes for the pupils and also authority to incur an expenditure of approximately $25 in having the floors cleaned and varnished.

In reply I have to say that our funds for the present fiscal year are extremely limited and the Department has found it necessary to discontinue the grant for prizes to Indian school pupils this summer. Ottawa, October 10th, 1930.

Memorandum,

Mr. Ferrier.

While at Odanak last week laying out the work in connection with the erection of a retaining wall along one side of the Abenakis School Convent lot, my attention was brought to certain alterations and improvements which are needed to the above mentioned school building and I was requested by the Superior to bring them to your attention for favourable consideration.

1. The plaster walls of the Superior's bedroom are cracked in several places and these could be repaired by covering them with linen finished with three coats of paint at a cost of $35.00.

2. The erection of a wooden partition in the dormitory to divide the room into three separate cells which partition could be built to a height of 7 ft. divided in panels, painted, etc., at a cost of $150.

3. Covering of the metal roof on the top of the addition used as an office with a thick coat of asphalt mastic at a cost of $15.00.

4. Repairing of the cement floor in the furnace room - $10.00.

5. The toilet for the boys at present consists of an outside building although there is a toilet room all furnished in the basement of the school, the use of which has been discontinued some years ago on account of lack of sufficient lighting. Now with the electric lighting installed all over the building, it would be advisable that the toilet room be provided with a tile floor and that the plumbing fixtures which consist of two water closets and one urinal, be put in a state of repair. This could be done at an approximate cost of $150.00.
Mr. Descoteau who is working on the construction of the retaining wall, would be willing to undertake the above mentioned work either by day labour or by contract. Should there be funds available this year, I would recommend that the contractor be authorized to proceed with these repairs while attending to the other work.

[Signature]

DEPARTMENTAL ENGINEER.
Oct. 20, 1930.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that you may arrange with Mr. Desrochers, contractor of Pierreville, to carry out the following repairs which are required at the Abenaki School Convent, in accordance with report submitted by the Departmental Engineer, after making an inspection of the building.

1. Covering of the plastered wall of the Superior's room with linen finished with three coats of oil paint.

2. Covering of the galvanized iron roof on the top of the addition used as office with thick coat of asphalt mastic in the manner already explained to Mr. Desrochers.

3. Repairing of the cement floor in the furnace room in the basement.

4. Construction of new floor in the boys' toilet in the basement using 6" red quarry tile, laid with half inch asphalt or cement joint.

5. Replacing closet tanks by new ones made of enamel iron also installing of new seats of the sanitary open front type.

6. Complete overhauling of the urinal and sewer pipe from the boys' toilet room.

7. Cleaning and painting of the inside of this toilet room as described to the contractor by the Engineer of the Department. Before this item is started, however, I would like to be furnished with an approximate estimate of the cost.

It is understood that the work is to be carried out by day labour as economically as possible, and you should arrange with the Superior to verify and certify to all accounts for materials and wages in connection with the work, which accounts should be forwarded in duplicate so that payment may be made direct by the Department.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo enclosing an estimate of the cost of the various items of repairs required at St. Joseph's Academy on the Pierreville Reserve.

In this connection I have to say that our funds for the balance of the present fiscal year are extremely limited, and it will, therefore, not be possible to authorize having all the work mentioned in the estimate which you submitted carried out. You may, however, arrange to have one column built under the verandah, and a coat of asbestos put on the office roof. The expenditure for this purpose should not exceed the estimate which you submitted, viz., $15 for the column under the verandah and $25 for the coat of asbestos for the office roof. You should arrange to have this work carried out at an early date, and, when completed, you should forward itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost. You should see that a satisfactory job is completed.

The other repairs mentioned will have to stand over until next spring, when our appropriation for the next fiscal year is available. You may, therefore, again draw the attention of the Department to these repairs next spring.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on conditions at Pierreville, Que.

While at Pierreville, Mr. William Watson, asked me if I would attend a meeting of the Indians at night as they had some matters they desired to place before me. As he called on me with the Chief, I consented to do so. Mr. Watson spoke, but evidently dealt only with matters which he had recently been taking up with the Department when at Ottawa. It may be as well to place a summary of his remarks on file.

Mr. Watson then launched into a long discourse on what he called patronage and said that the Indian was being discriminated against. He mentioned such work as the aforementioned wall, the bridge, and cited an instance in connection with the local Indian school. He stated that he had ascertained, at Ottawa, that the mere hanging of the blinds on the school windows had cost $83.00. I asked if this did not include also the price of the blinds but he said not. I had no personal information on the matter but expressed doubt as to the correctness of the figure.

C. C. Parker,

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your account of the 25th ultimo for cleaning at the St. Frances R. C. Indian Day School. Apparently, no authority has ever been given for incurring this expenditure, but a review of our files shows that, from time to time, you have submitted similar accounts, which have been paid.

It is considered that it would be better to place the payments for the cleaning of this school on a more satisfactory basis and it has therefore been decided that the sum of $4 per teaching month will be allowed for the purpose. At the end of the June, December and March quarters, you may submit a voucher for $12, and, at the end of September, a voucher for $4. These vouchers should be made out in favour of the Principal of the St. Frances R. C. School, and a cheque in payment will be sent direct to her. She can then make whatever arrangements she considers necessary for cleaning the school.

It is intended that this amount should cover all cleaning and caretaking required at this school. While the amount promised in this letter is $40 a year, it will be subject, during the current academic year, to a deduction of 10%.

In view of the new arrangement being made in connection with the work at this school, the account which you submitted is not being paid and is returned with this letter. You may submit a voucher covering the amount due the Sister Superior from April first to June 30th, 1932, at the rate mentioned in the first part of this letter.

Your obedient servant,

T. H. L. MacInnes,

Odanak, Dec. 5, 1932.

Sir:

A few words to inform you that the Department has not yet sent the first month for the heating at the Convent of the Grey Nuns of Odanak. That account was sent on the 24th of October, 1932 and we are without news since. I would be very happy to receive the account due of $15.00 which is due since the 24th of October, 1932. Furthermore, I would be glad to know the reason why I was cut off $1.50 on the sum of $15.00, seeing that it is written in the Indian Act that the Indians are not to be taxed, yet they make me pay a tax of 10%. I wish you would give me an explanation as soon as possible and at the same time the sum of $15.00 for the heating during one month from the 24th of September to the 24 of October. This was sent by Agent Maurecourt but we have not received any reply since.

I would then be glad to receive that money before next month, as soon as possible.

Your devoted servant,

Joseph Robert,
Odanak.

November 13, 1933.

Dear Sir,

Referring to the request made by Sister Mary Josephine of the Abenakis School Convent at Odanak, that some repairs be made to the double windows and the screens, which are reported to be in poor condition, would it not be possible for this year to have the double windows made air tight by caulking them with a cheap felt weather stripping, or some similar material, as I understand that some of these windows will have to be entirely renewed next year.

I was advised also that the screens are in need of being replaced owing to their dilapidated condition, and these repairs could be attended to early next spring when funds are made available for work of this kind.

I would ask that you communicate with the Superior of the Convent as early as possible, and advise if such arrangements are possible and will be satisfactory to her.

Yours very truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of Jan 3/34 No. 23-2-5 concerning the acc. of $3.50 in favour of Mr. Robert for carting away from the school yard at St. Joseph's Academy. I do not say that there is in fact no authority for this expenditure, but in view of the fact that the children could not possibly go to school without matching their way in almost two feet of snow and mud then obliged to take off their shoes to dry them out, or not catch cold, I found it proper to have this sum removed.

As to the possibility of having this expense incurred by the children themselves, I cannot see how these small children could have done it even if they had had the necessary implements and the warm clothes to face this very extraordinary cold weather we are facing through since the middle of Dec., there was too much risk.

Hoping this explanation will be found satisfactory, I remain, your truly,
