To the Deputy Minister

Sir:

I beg to report that on the 20th of June I left Ottawa according to your instructions, to inspect the following reserves: Beaucecourt, Pierreville, Lorette, Seven-Islands, Bersimis, Restigouche, Maria, Gacoune, Les Acounains, and Pointe Bleue which were visited in the order above mentioned.

Pierreville

I found that the ice from the roof had fallen on the front verandah and damaged it. There is a large hole on the left side of the roof and I would recommend that some repairs be done to it. The cost would amount to about $8.00. There are also two cellar windows needing repairs. The sills are completely gone on one and half rotten on the other, the frames are also in very bad condition. Cost of repairs $4.00

(sgd) Henri Fabien
To the Deputy Minister

Sir:

I beg to report that on the 25th of June I left Ottawa according to your instructions, to inspect the following reserves: Beaucevoir, Pierreville, Lorette, Seven-Islands, Berthierville, Restigouche, Maria, Cascoune, Les Assomains, and Pointe Bleue which were visited in the order above mentioned.

The roof of the small office at the rear, between the two wings of the building would need to be done over; the snow in winter accumulates on this small roof and as this roof is not double the heat from under melts the ice above and the water runs through the roof and along the walls. Dr. Maurault asked Mr. Descoteaux to make an estimate of the cost of a new roof and his reply is on file.

(sgd) Henri Fabien
To the Deputy Minister

Sir:

I beg to report that on the 30th of June I left Ottawa according to your instructions, to inspect the following reserves: Beauceur, Pierreville, Lorette, Seven-Islands, Bersimis, Restigouche, Maria, Cacouna, Les Escoumins, and Pointe Bleue which were visited in the order above mentioned.

Pierreville

I visited the school of the Sisters on the reserve and I was informed, in accordance with Mr. P. Phelan's request, that there are 50 lights (60) and a washing machine in the laundry on the same meter, while the heater, the stove, the electric iron and electric refrigerator were operated on a special contract.

The laundry requires new electric wiring.

(sgd) Henri Fabien
Ottawa, August 30, 1934.

Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 15th ultimo, enclosing a quotation which you received for the reshingling of the roof of the small office at the rear of the St. Joseph's Academy, the repairs required to the roof of the front verandah and the two cellar windows, I would say that the Department will have no funds this year to provide for the cost of reshingling the roof of the small office.

Mr. Fabien, who recently visited the school, states that the cost of repairing the roof of the verandah would be approximately $8.00 and the repairs to the cellar windows should not exceed $8.00. The Department understands that there is a competent carpenter, Jules O'Bomsawin, who could satisfactorily carry out the repairs to the roof of the verandah and the cellar windows. If you consider that the work can be completed for the amount mentioned above—which should include the cost of any material and labour required—you may arrange for Indian labour to carry out these repairs. Please obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of the material, and prepare a voucher, in triplicate, for the labour. These, you should certify and forward for payment.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir,

Last winter, at his request, the Sisters of St. Joseph's Academy went to the school and taught every day just a substantial lunch for the children of their school, especially the underfed children of this school, and they were quite a few.

I am glad to report that the results were good. The children pulled through this very severe winter very well.

Up to this time, this winter the children did not have much trouble getting the winter in rather warm, if not comfort to last; but there is actually a few children who are having to feel the strain and would need help, food, good food, well prepared well served.

This the Sisters are prepared to do, if the Department will allow, as last winter, the sum of $5.00 a week to buy this food from now to say the 15th April. I believe it would be of great help to these children.

Odanak, June 19th 1935

To Brother Maurice, Agent

Sir,

You asked me some explanations about the heating; here it is:

The temperature having been too cold to stop heating on the 15th May as ordered by the Department, we had to ask Mr. Robert, with your consent, to kindly continue his work for a few days, as the children were liable to catch cold on account of lack of heat.

For the cleaning of the cellar, of the furnaces, of the coal bin and the slope where the ashes are thrown, the Department has always paid that sum of $2.00 for many years. If this was then necessary it must be so again today. I beg you, Sir, to kindly explain this to the Department and solicit in favour of Mr. Robert payment of the balance of his account amounting to $7.50.

You would oblige your humble servant,

(Signed) M. Josephine, Superior.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Huskard,

Referring to my memorandum of the 15th ultimo in connection with an offer made in 1932 by Mr. Charles Edward Desrochers of Pierreville, Quebec, for the renewal of some twenty double windows in the old portion of the Abenakis School Convent at Odanak on the Abenakis Reserve, Quebec. I beg now to advise that Mr. Desrochers has sent in another offer giving a more detailed description of the work to be completed for the amount of his offer, which is the same as that previously made in 1932, namely, $225.00.

The work involved in this offer consists in the renewal of twenty windows with double sashes, located in the old section of the building, by new ones made of dry pine, glazed complete, and provided with wire screens, all to be well-adjusted and fitted with necessary hardware, such as handles, hooks, fasteners and so forth, well painted with three coats of oil paint. It is understood that all materials and workmanship are to be of good quality and that the old windows are to remain the property of Mr. Desrochers. The work if authorized at the present would be complete by the beginning of October.

As mentioned in my previous memorandum as there are funds available from School Appropriation and as Mr. Desrochers's offer appears reasonable, I would recommend that it be accepted, and that his work be subject to the approval of an officer of the department.

The Secretary,

Dear Sir,

I have the honour to submit for your consideration our new lightning rod in pure copper approved by the Department of Public Works of the Province of Quebec.

I will make this installation on the public hall, the convent, outhouses, etc., at Odanak village at a very moderate price. You are aware that each year lightning does considerable damage and that it is dangerous for the inhabitants. These lightning rods are subject to inspection by the Quebec electricians.

Hoping that you will give my proposal due consideration, and that I will receive a favourable answer in order to give you our best quotations and to be favoured with the order.

Yours very truly,

Ministry of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

May I ask you, in the name of all the children of this school, some rewards for the closing of this classical year?

In the past, the Department has been very generous; we hope this year, it will be the same.

The attendance was good, in spite of the poverty of the children. Some of them were half clothed. We would like to give something useful, as: toilet soap, pen-knives, beads, wool, handkerchiefs, apron, towels and books.

A sum of twenty dollars is generally what is authorized by the Department. We would appreciate very much this new mark of kindness in favor of our children.

Referring to your twelfth instant, 25-8-4, we wish to inform you that we now have on hand the Requisition including the three articles mentioned in same.

We find it very peculiar that you can not find any request for arithmetic, catechisms, etc. We have made inquiries concerning same, and Agent Maurault says he sent it in with the others. The Requisition List included three sheets. It seems a whole sheet is missing. We had mentioned on it that a number of the books were especially for Manual Training. We are now including a list of some of the books not received and the most needed.

With regard to the accounts for cleaning, after inquiries, we were told they have been sent in also. There is a misunderstanding concerning the Cheque mentioned in your letter. This account for $15.75 in favour of A. Lapierre was not for cleaning and scrubbing, but, for supplies such as brooms, paint, toilet paper, etc., and a few articles for manual training. Here again, we include a duplicate of the accounts. We have already sent the accounts with the receipts to the Agent. On your request we will send them in duplicate.

You will find enclosed a detailed list of the children who badly need clothes same as we have already sent one to the

(Agent)
Agent. Out of the number, a few are still coming to school, but very poorly dressed. Luckily the weather has not been too severe yet.

The delay in answering to your favour is due to the fact of getting inquiries from Agent Maurault who has been away to his sister's funeral.

We trust this will be satisfactory to you,

We remain,

Truly yours,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the first instant, you may expend an amount not exceeding $40.00 in repairs and cleaning at the St. Frances R. C. Indian Day School.

Regarding the last paragraph of your letter, we do not appear to have the estimate which you state you forwarded, in connection with the cost of painting the exterior of the building. If Indian labour is not available, you should let me know for what price you could have the exterior of the building painted. In this event you should state the name and address of any person who gives you a quotation on the painting.

Il en est de même pour un réfrigérateur. Les vagues de grande chaleur... le besoin de congélation extra-rapide... et les nombreuses occasions où vous demandez au réfrigérateur de faire des merveilles... pour tout cela, il faut nécessairement une réserve d'énergie suffisante. Et cette réserve vous la trouverez dans le réfrigérateur Westinghouse. Elle assure votre tranquillité, vous savez que votre Westinghouse vous fournira une congélation rapide et une énergie suffisante pour vos besoins, par tous les temps les plus chauds. Elle assure aussi plus longue durée à l'appareil qui fonctionne sans effort et sans épuisements.

Le mécanisme n'est jamais soumis à un effort et ne travaille pas au-delà de sa capacité. Il ne coûte rien quand il est inactif, mais il est toujours prêt à la tâche pour assurer une réfrigération efficace et sûre, si haut que monte le marché ou quel que soit le travail que vous en exigez.

L'énergie de réserve du mécanisme hermétiquement scellé conserve à votre réfrigérateur toute son utilité, lui assurant une longue durée et une réfrigération très économique.

Vous comment cette réserve de capacité du Westinghouse intervient. À la température d'été, 80 degrés, le mécanisme Westinghouse fonctionne encore 20 minutes par heure. Il reste donc 40 minutes ou une réserve maximale de réfrigération. Confirming our conversation last Tuesday regarding refrigerator at the Convent, Odanak.

The cost of replacing present brine tank with a new coil, fitting new control, expansion valve, including labour would be approximately $55.00 with guarantee of one year on entire machine. However, as we pointed out, the refrigerator is too large for your requirements with resulting unnecessarily high operating costs. In view of this, we think it would be to your advantage, instead of making an outlay of $55.00 upon the old machine to purchase a smaller domestic type refrigerator. We could furnish from stock a new Westinghouse Model E-55 with one year complete guarantee and a further four years guarantee on the sealed refrigerator mechanism only as per our standard contract below.

This refrigerator would operate on about 45 K.W.Hrs per month or on your rate about $1.12 for this period. Price would be $220.00 with an allowance of $65.00 for the old equipment complete including Fabian Box making a cash amount due for the new machine $155.00.

This is a special price as we have only two of these machines left from last year. They are absolutely new and shown in attached booklet.

The offer is subject to your acceptance before October 31st, 1938.

Thanking you for your courtesy and trusting this letter gives required information.

February, 25, 1939.

M. R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Referring to the request made to Doctor Maurault, Agent, concerning the authorization for clearing the snow.......

We were informed, yesterday, that the Department objects against such expense, owing to lack of funds.

We wish to call your attention on this. We are just about to be buried under snow. Banks attain from ten to twelve feet and some of the windows are thus completely blocked. Moreover, the weight of the snow will cause damage to the building. We have also experienced, in the past years, that after heavy snowfalls as we have had, the sudden melting has caused the water to run into the basement to considerable extent.

We therefore think it urgent to clear away the snow immediately in order to avoid all ill consequence; and...this cannot be done by children.

We take this opportunity to inform you also, that, the pupils are too frequently missing school. Reasons are the following: SICKNESS....some due to the wearing of "rubbers"; Others, living some distance away, cannot come through the banks which are blocking the road; they have had but a few days of school since January. Others are kept at home to work at baskets or canoes and yet, the poor people cannot get money enough to buy clothes for the children. It is really pitiful at some places. Never we've had such a poor attendance.

We thought it better to advise you of the situation ourselves and we sincerely trust you will take it under serious consideration at once.

We remain, truly yours,

Principal.

Saint-Francois R.C. Indian Day School.
Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of another letter from the Principal of the St. Francis R.C. school with reference to clearing the snow from the school yard.

It is considered that you should be able to arrange to have the necessary work done by some of those who are receiving relief. In this way there will be no extra cost to the Department.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

B. Maurault, Esq., M. D.,
Indian Agent,
Pierreville, Que.
